Configuring Automatic Enrollment (Option B) ensures that devices are automatically enrolled in Microsoft Intune during the out-of-box experience (OBE). This allows for seamless device management and ensures that Intune policies can be applied to these devices.

Selecting a Windows Autopilot deployment profile for self-deploying mode (Option D) is suitable when you want devices to be deployed to users without any user interaction. This is useful when you’re delivering computers directly to users, and you want a streamlined setup where users are prompted to sign in and the device is configured without requiring their manual intervention.

Together, these components (Automatic Enrollment and a Windows Autopilot deployment profile for self-deploying mode) provide an automated and user-friendly process for setting up Windows 11 computers in your Azure AD tenant with Microsoft Intune for efficient management and security.

questions.question_text:
You need to assign the same deployment profile to all the computers that are configured by using Windows Autopilot.

Which two actions should you perform? Each correct answer presents part of the solution.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
ZTDid tag and assign the deployment profile to the dynamic group.

Ref: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/autopilot/enrollment-autopilot#:~:text=To%20create%20a%20group%20that%20includes%20all%20of%20your%20Autopilot%20devices%2C%20enter%3A%20(device.devicePhysicalIDs%20%2Dany%20(_%20%2DstartsWith%20%22%5BZTDid%5D%22))

Selected Answer: AC
seems correct

Answer is correct. (A and C) 
A: To add all devices automatically to Autopilot you have to create a dynamic device group with following query: (device.devicePhysicalIDs -any (_ -startsWith "[ZTDid]")).
With this all devices, which are added in Autopilot will be a member in this group.
C: After that you assign this group to the deployment profile.

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP
-

You have a Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT) deployment share that has a path of D:\MDTShare.

You need to add a feature pack to the boot image.

Which three actions should you perform in sequence? To answer, move the appropriate actions from the list of actions to the answer area and arrange them in the correct order.

//IMG//

discussion.content: MDT is being deleted as of 26 April 2024.

1. Copy the feature pack to D:\MDTShare\Tools\x86.
2. Modify the Windows PE properties of the deployment share.
3. Update the deployment share.

Explanation:
Step 1: Copy the feature pack to D:\MDTShare\Tools\x86
Add a feature pack, DaRT 10 (part of MDOP 2015), to the boot images.
1. Copy the CAB files to the deployment share: MDTShare\Tools\x86
2. In the Deployment Workbench, right-click the MDTShare deployment share and select Properties.

Step 2: Modify the Windows PE properties of the deployment share
3. On the Windows PE tab, in the Platform drop-down list, make sure x86 is selected.
4. On the Features sub tab, select the Microsoft Diagnostics and Recovery Toolkit (DaRT) checkbox.

Step 3: Update the deployment share
Like the MDT Build Lab deployment share, the MDT Production deployment share needs to be updated after it has been configured. This is the process during which the Windows PE boot images are created.

Answer is correct.
